intro: Agathophyllum cupulare, commonly known as the hooded sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Australia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its small, white or pinkish flowers. The plant has a low-growing, sprawling habit with hairy stems and leaves that are often covered in fine, white hairs. Its fruit is a small, dry schizocarp that splits into two one-seeded parts when mature. Agathophyllum cupulare is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments and is often found in sandy soils.
